title: What will be the domestic box office gross in the opening week for Quentin Tarantino's Once Upon a Time In Hollywood, according to Box Office Mojo?
preds:
Making significant revisions to utilize BoxOfficeReport's official opening weekend prediction of $39MM just published [1], which has a much longer track record than the model [2] I created and used previously in absence of any official prediction. Forecasted mean falls from $73MM to $52.6MM. B3 increases from 11% to 74%, B4 falls from 64% to 19%. Cc @Emil @Hammer-Time I'm still using my model's addition of 35% on top to extrapolate to full week from just the weekend, as well as the model's calculated standard deviation using the new mean.  Forecasted mean: $52,651,716
Standard deviation: $8,430,394 Crowd: 9%, 29%, 29%, 22%, 11% [1] http://www.boxofficereport.com/predictions/predictions.html
[2] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/883427
Whoa - I missed opening WEEK (thank you @dglid).

Reducing as Lion King ($192MM last weekend) seems to be playing in more theatres. Second was Spider-Man ($21MM). Thinking Tarantino will pass $20MM by virtue of being new, difficult to say if it will get to $40MM (which I previously favoured ).

Reducing my distribution due to a better understanding of past Tarantino box office revenue numbers (see discussion here https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/888173) which suggest that a week above $60 million would be a strong outlier.
One last update after I read Emil's nice analysis.

In this post, I want to see what Tarantino's base rates imply for this question. I took data on openings (I assume this refers to opening day) of 10 movies and the box office revenues from [1]. Further I multiply by 2 to get what would be the opening weekend and and raised estimates by 35% (estimated by @dglid) to account for revenues after the weekend and into the next 5 days as this question refers to "week". The average is 41 million with a standard deviation of 35.  This means that the forecast I initially relied on implies this movie will be an outlier for Tarantino, which leads me to lower the distribution slightly by a few percentage points. On the other hand, Sony is reportedly projecting an opening of $30 mill. [2] which would indeed place this moving at the high end of the distribution. [1] https://www.boxofficemojo.com/people/chart/?view=Director&id=tarantino.htm&sort=opengross&order=DESC&p=.htm
[2] https://www.thewrap.com/once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-quentin-tarantino-box-office/

There is a good analysis by @dglid here: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/883427 His data shows that historically, given the number of trailer views the movie has received, one would expect (based on linear extrapolation, to oversimplify) that weekly revenue would be 72.8 mill with an SD of 10.7. The opening of competing moves is not accounted for in this analysis but there aren't other big movies opening the same weekend. Lion King has a similar opening date but it already came out and should therefore have less of an effect.

Updating model [1] with refreshed YouTube trailer counts. I think a lot of forecasters are not taking into account that the question asks for opening _week_, not just weekend. I project ~$54MM opening weekend and another ~$18MM for the rest of the first week. That does seem a bit high, but my assumption is based on data from the past three years that in this week of the year, the total weekly revenue was about 35% higher than the weekend revenue. Forecasted mean: $72,813,357
Standard deviation: $10,723,167 Crowd: 10%, 46%, 26%, 12%, 6% [1] https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZN2wk0VBJpuMyQy0ZZqL-1qJw8m_biLuuz5yo9n9hTE/edit#gid=1268209806

There is hardly any movie of this drama/Thriller kind running/starting at the time of opening weekend. This mainly the whole summer has been children movies almost every week one after another. Based on Quentin Tarantino's other successful movies, it is likely to get some attention in later time. First week will be average to low average.
Past opening weekends, friends interest in seeing
Tarantino films tend to make money over a longer period of time. With Brad and Leo there is a chance of bucking the trend and breaking the $40M barrier.
A good weekly gross is somewhere in 250m range. There are not too many big films scheduled for release it seems. This one has had fair amount of advance publicity and good reviews. So should do well.

Updated model [1] with most recent trailer stats. Minor change from yesterday. Forecasted mean: $71,756,107
Standard deviation: $10,567,467 Crowd: 6%, 29%, 44%, 13%, 8% [1] https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZN2wk0VBJpuMyQy0ZZqL-1qJw8m_biLuuz5yo9n9hTE/edit#gid=1268209806
Only one other movie has top name in the list and that is Lion King.

His last film grossed less than $20,000,000 so possibly this will be similar, but the last film  looks like a blip - previous films have made between $20 and 40m and I think this bracket is most likely. It also has good critical reviews so far. However adjusting for inflation the next film may push over $40m but I think it's unlikely it would go above $60m.

Model [1] steps: 
1. Gather data from BoxOfficeReport [2] on YouTube trailer views for this movie
2. Gather data from BoxOfficeReport [3] on historical ratio between YouTube trailer view counts and opening weekend revenue
3. Create projection of opening weekend revenue based on YouTube trailer views via simple linear trendline
4. Calculate standard deviation using average variation of BoxOfficeReport's prediction vs. actual revenues [4] for other movies predicted to have opening weekend revenue within $10M of forecasted mean.
5. Gather historical YouTube trailer view counts at various dates before release date using Wayback Machine scrapes of BoxOfficeReport. [5]
6. Adjust projected final YouTube trailer view count based on above linear correlation between YouTube trailer view counts X days before release and final YouTube trailer view count.
7. Gather 10 years of data from BoxOfficeMojo [6] on seasonality box office trends
8. Adjust projection of opening weekend revenue based on seasonality
9. Gather 3 years of data from BoxOfficeMojo on weekly box office revenue [7]
10. Project weekly revenue using average % increase of same week's weekly box office revenues from opening weekend revenues Forecasted mean: $71,594,056
Standard deviation: $10,543,601 Crowd: 10%, 30%, 40%, 15%, 5% [1] https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ZN2wk0VBJpuMyQy0ZZqL-1qJw8m_biLuuz5yo9n9hTE/edit#gid=1268209806
[2] http://www.boxofficereport.com/trailerviews/trailerviews.html
[3] http://www.boxofficereport.com/trailerviews/owyoutuberatios.html
[4] http://www.boxofficereport.com/predictions/predictionsscorecard.html
[5] https://web.archive.org/web/*/http://www.boxofficereport.com/trailerviews/trailerviews.html
https://www.boxofficemojo.com/weekend/
[6] https://www.boxofficemojo.com/weekend/
[7] https://www.boxofficemojo.com/weekly/

His last 3 movies have grossed from 4.6 to 30 million averaging around 24million. The higher end figures seem unlikely. 12/25/15 	The Hateful Eight 	W	$4,610,676 	
12/25/12 	Django Unchained 	$30,122,888
8/21/09 	Inglourious Basterds 	       $38,054,676
Leaning toward high side as limited other releases.

Numbers are low for several reasons:
I'm not seeing much "mainstream" advertising
It's not a summer blockbuster Star Wars or Marvel type film
It's getting later in the Summer--burnout
Manson is kinda played out--younger generations don't know/care
It's not a superhero movie. Good reviews. Tarantino lost some of his shine but he still has fans.
There are many invaluable artists, but due to the season maybe some ...
I just put the last six movies of each of Brad Pitt, Leo DiCaprio, and Quentin Tarantino into a histogram.

If it rolls out like a typical Tarantino movie, it would seem that every theater it shows at gets around 10 million. The current trend of movies like this seem to be open in around 3,800 theaters. Giving you a number right around 38 million on open. Add a little extra hype from the cast and ratings, I think this movie will land right in the 40 - 60 million range easily.

Box Office Mojo for Tarantino shows diminishing performance for opening weekend in last three movies from $38M, $30M and $5M limited and $16M wide[1]. That translated to $54M, $33M and $22M wide (same source, but movie).  There are some projections already for the weekend [2] in the region of $30M, maybe $25M, which for the week would be closer to the last two movies (range $33M - $22M), but both of them in December. Maybe this is a factor to consider. About the movie, it got 92% in the Tomatometer [3], not a guarantee of anything with audience, but a good reference, with DiCaprio and Pitt as attraction. Just to compare, the previous three movies got 88%, 86% and 72% [4]. It got 9.6/10 in IMDb (8.3, 8.4 and 7.8). Critics are expressly mentioning that they would not reveal the end, another indicator, and while not the typical Tarantino's movie, it seems it gets close to a masterpiece (not being one). So, saving 1% and 5% for <$20M and >$60M, 30% up to $40M and 64% more than $40M. [1] https://www.boxofficemojo.com/people/chart/?view=Director&id=tarantino.htm&sort=date&order=ASC&p=.htm
[2] https://deadline.com/2019/07/quentin-tarantinos-once-upon-a-time-in-hollywood-eyes-30m-opening-1202641601/
[3] https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/once_upon_a_time_in_hollywood
[4] https://www.rottentomatoes.com/celebrity/quentin_tarantino
[5] https://www.imdb.com/title/tt7131622/

Lately, show-biz pundits have been estimating the first week take downward. I think this may be hype to make a record opening (for Tarantino) look all the more impressive. This is looking like something akin to the definitive Quentin Tarantino movie, so I don't think comparisons with his earlier efforts are quite apt. I think even people who are not die-hard fans will not want to wait to see this one.
